body:
## What

Fills out the crawl DAO

Requesting review from @aluttik and @kitified , CC @microsoftly for visibility

## Why

Used in task queueing service for discovery tasks

https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/627
https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/628
https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/630

## How

1. Fills out the DAO for inserting a new crawl
2. Adds tests
3. Removes similar code from the component service (minus the race condition plus the extra DAO layering)

## Security Impact

NA -- none

title: [ramjet] Fill out crawler dao
body:
## What

Fill out crawler DAO

Requesting review from @aluttik , CC @microsoftly for visibility

## Why

We need to make use of the crawler recording DAO setup for discovery task queueing. Also minimize duplication code so we remove the `findOrCreateCrawler` in component service (chose to keep this DAO one because it's slightly simpler / no race condition)

https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/627
https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/628 
https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/630

## How

1. Add to DAO
2. Remove from component-service

Please note that types are being defined into the database DAO -- per offline discussion, we're splitting the `DTO` pacakge so that each type is defined with the logical layer that it's used in (ie. the DAO package is responsible for the types of it's DTO / externally visible interface). This is intentional

## Security Impact

Checklist:
- [x] Code in this PR is covered by automated tests.


## Dependency Changes

NA -- none

title: [ramjet] Fill out analysis task queue logic (no more deadlock!)
body:
## What

Add queueing logic for analysis tasks

Requesting review from  any/either of @aluttik or @kitified or  @microsoftly , CC @microsoftly for visibility

## Why

Central part of the process for writing a "Analysis Task Queueing Service"
Further detail here https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/627 https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/628 https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/631

## How

Manually tested agains `curl -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X POST -d '{ "componentIDs": [ "12345678-910a-bcde-f123-45678910abcd" ], "declaredLicenseScan": true, "discoveredLicenseScan": true, "commentStrippedSHA256": true }' http://localhost:8678/api/analysis` & similar. Next step is adding automated tests and testing more thoroughly. This will be handled in a separate PR for the sake of review.

1. Fix the blocking threading issue introduced to manual-task-pusher during git conflicts
2. Fill out logic for analysis task launching!

## Security Impact

NA -- none

## Dependency Changes

NA -- none

title: Added filename prioritization for determining a Declared Project License
body:
## What

IPR.Detect will now take filename into account when deciding on a declared project license.

## Why

Currently the component DB has a ton of components where the declared_license_source is a README file and it should be LICENSE.

Part of #620 

## How

When determining a declared project license, if there's a tie for prioritization in the categories of SPDX validity, depth of file in project, and license type (e.g. explicit expression, nomos scanned, downloaded from URL), IPR will then check filenames to determine which license to pick.

The filename priorities are currently:
```
LICENSE*
NOTICE*
COPYING*
README*
```

This does not affect other declared license files like `*.nuspec` or `pom.xml` because those have a higher priority `IPR.LicenseType`.

## Checklist
- [x] Code in this PR is covered by automated tests.

title: Added max file size to expander
body:
## What

This PR is more of a suggestion. I'd like to start a conversation about this before merging and I don't mind changing any part of it or just closing it if that's what we think is best.

This change would make it so that empty files with a `!_fossa.toobig_!` suffix would be added in place of decompressing files that would be >10GB in size when decompressed.

## Why

Sometimes when expanding we'll run into issues where the uncompressed size of a file will be like >60GB. This takes up a lot of space and CPU for the component analysis workers, and I'm not sure if the fingerprint we'd get out of it is worth the cost and possible complications.

## How

When we know the uncompressed size of an archived file, we can just create an empty file in its place if it is too big.

## Checklist
- [x] Code in this PR is covered by automated tests.

title: [ramjet] Wrap up state tracking transitions

labels.name: in review
labels.description: Signify that the PR is in review

body:
## What

Replaces https://github.com/fossas/basis/pull/623, per newer discussion

Mandate state tracking transitions for components (eg. a component can not jump to being "in progress" without first being queued)

Requesting review from either @aluttik @microsoftly , CC @microsoftly 

## Why

Logically, component states should transition in logical ways (eg. should not jump directly from Failed to InProgress). This PR enforces these transitions

Further discussion & detail here:
https://github.com/fossas/basis/issues/549
https://teamfossa.slack.com/archives/C0155DXDMP1/p1599178239054500

## How

1. Update to use squirrel library to build queries
2. We allow these transitions
```
Unalyzed -> Queued
Queued -> InProgress, Queued (may clear queue and need to requeue)
InProgress -> Analyzed, Failed, Queued (may succeed, fail. May also timeout and then be cleared from faktory or have us scale down kube midway through analysis)
Analyzed -> Queued  (may need too be re-analyzed at some point if we want certain components to be scanned with a different scan type)
Failed -> Queued (may requeue if failed due to rate-limiting)
```
3. Add tests for these cases
4. Update other integration tests which rely on state

## Security Impact


Checklist:
- [x] Code in this PR is covered by automated tests.
- [ ] New inputs in this PR are validated and sanitized (example: user input or data read from other systems).

## Dependency Changes

NA (makes use of Squirrel, which is already used throughout basis)

title: Ninja Build Graph Tables
body: Adds DB tables for Ninja build graph data. I'm OOO this week, so feel free to merge if LGTM'd.

title: ghost files support in scotland yard
body:
## What

This PR adds support for expanded archive files (Ghost Files) in Scotland Yard.

UI Mocks: https://www.figma.com/file/sNe1Y0Aa7c93NxXGpxCDSe/VPS%3A-Archive-in-File-Tree?node-id=0%3A1

## Why

In order to show users the scan results of files inside of their archives, we needed to turn this feature on when importing file inferences from Sherlock

## How

This PR consists of a few changes:

1) Add query param "?full=true" in the call to `sherlock` from the `scotland-yard-worker`. This will tell `sherlock` to include ghost files in the response

2) Add a migration to the Scotland Yard DB that adds a new column to `scan_files` named `is_expanded`. If an original file was expanded, we mark this column as `true` in the DB. 

3) Modify the Materialized view to include `is_archive`, which basically checks if a directory ends with `!_fossa.virtual_!`. If it does, we know that the folder is an expanded archive, and we will return this in the API

4) Modify the `ListFiles` endpoint to return
  - display file path `filePath` which is the file path stripped of occurrences of `!_fossa.virtual_!` so we don't show that in the UI.
  - `fullFilePath` which includes the full path, so the UI can make correct queries to SY. 
  - `isGhostFile` - is the file part of an archive
  - `isArchive` - is the file an expanded archive

We also will by default ignore the original archive if we have the expanded contents. This is to minimize confusion in the UI (they would see both a folder and a file with the same name)

## Security Impact

No Security impact AFAICT

Checklist:
TODO

## Dependency Changes

None

title: Add LicenseBoundariesType field to IPR.File
body:
Requested by VPS team.

Add a field to an IPR.File that describes what license boundary expansion strategy was used to set the offsets/line numbers in the license expression.

It can be one of these strings:
```
none
binary
code
special
text
```

When there are no `LicenseExpressions`, the field should be `"none"`.

title: Faktory queue based pod autoscaling
body:
# Description
Add service that allows kube analysis worker deployments to proportionally scale to a defined _max_ number of pods based on the size of a taskqueue in faktory.

# Equation
There are three variables that determine pod counts
* `queueSize`: the size of the queue
* `podStepSize`: configurable, the desired number of messages in the queue per pod. 
* `maxPods`: configurable, the max scale of pods that can be running
```
PodCount=
  MIN(
    CIELING(QSize/stepSize),
    maxPods
  )
```

# Acceptance Criteria
* Checks for changes in pod scale are performed every 5 minutes


The following scenarios are met (test fixture):
| queue size | queue-pod step size | max pods | current pod count | ∆ in pod count | final pod count |
|------------|---------------------|----------|-------------------|----------------|-----------------|
|          0 |                1000 |       10 |                 9 |             -9 |               0 |
|       1000 |                1000 |       10 |                 2 |             -1 |               1 |
|       5000 |                1000 |       10 |                 2 |              3 |               5 |
|   90000000 |                1000 |       10 |                 0 |             10 |              10 |
|         15 |                   5 |       10 |                 0 |              3 |               3 |
|          1 |                   5 |       10 |                 4 |             -3 |               1 |

title: Update GH workflows and documentation for tagged releases
update fossa/f2-kube to use helm charts

Update fossas/f2-kube to use helm charts for spot workers.

* helm chart templates out a spot worker
* values defined for: `default`, `rpm`, and `aosp` queue workers
* README updated with description on how to setup helm and manually deploy with helm

title: Kube/Deployment improvements
body:
# Description
The ramjet deployment pipeline is currently heavily manual and hard to test. There are several small wins we can get, and this story captures the first part of them. 

# Helm
Parameterize f2-kube yaml files into helm charts for simpler deployments and less repetitive overhead.

# Tagged + Manual Releases
Support building images that we intend to deploy based on tags, with the option to support manually specified tags.

# Kind-ly local test 
Add tooling to allow testing with [kind](https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/). This will unlock the ability to more rapidly test features that rely on kube (e.g. autoscaling)

# Queue Size Based Autoscaling
Update deployment pod count based on the size of a faktory queue.

## Future Work
Future work may require more advanced autoscaling control: e.g. multiple inputs like rate of failure for a queue (e.g. 80% of tasks are failing, so autoscale down until that number reaches an acceptable threshold or pod count goes to 0)

# Simple Deployment Flow
Deploy on merge to certain tag/branch structures.

title: Component Domain HTTP and Client API pseudo code draft
body:
## What

This PR provides a draft of the shape of the HTTP and client interfaces that will interact with the knowlege API. This draft only supports public data.

As noted in the code, this is written in typescript because our intended final model has a lot of disjoint unions, which I find much easier to express in typescript with generics than via explicit enumeration in golang.

The pseudo code is very terse, let me know if you want me to go back and sprinkle in more comments to make what is happening and what does what more clear.

## Why

To get buy in on the design before more work is put into the design. I tried to encompass what functionality was needed from the knowledge API as described in the high level unified scan doc as well as other low hanging fruit for the API as a whole.

body:
story #691 
# Description
Deploy analysis workers for nuget, queue analysis jobs, and monitor for edge cases from data in the wild
# Acceptance Criteria
* Push nuget components to queue `NUGET-analysis` with:
  * commenStrippedSha and declaredLicenseScan enabled
  * discoveredLicnse scan disabled
  * 30 min timeout
  * 3 retries
* add a nuget analysis worker kube deployment in f2-kube repo
* deploy worker that consumes from `NUGET-analysis` queue
* [passive] monitor for unexpected errors and rate limits using kibana. [go/ramjet-worker-dashboard](http://go/ramjet-worker-dashboard) is a good starting point.
* [passive] monitor max/min pod memory and cpu usage. Adjust worker pod resource limits and requests to support more efficient pod packing per node.

title: nuget discovery implementation
body:
Story #691 
# Description
Create nuget component discovery worker(s) and endpoints to trigger discovery
# Acceptance Criteria
1. new crawler `nuget` is added to the db
1. new registry is added to the DB. 
1. add `POST` endpoint that supports the new crawler, registry pair: `[POST] /api/crawler/:crawler/:registryID` see #627 for reference
1. faktory worker that consumes task sent to queue by step 1 and starts nuget discovery
1. discovery crawls and the payloads that trigger them are recorded in the DB and associated with all components discovered in the crawl
1. newly discovered components are added to the component database. 
1. metadata that does not align with the current columns should be inserted into the `additional_metadata` column.
1. if possible, record metadata about the crawl so that subsequent discovery crawls will not redo the same work

title: Nuget Coverage
body:
# Description
* Create a golang based discovery crawler for nuget to gather C# coverage. 
* Extend existing analysis worker to be compatible with nuget components.

# Acceptance Criteria
## Discovery
### Code Changes
1. new crawler `nuget` is added to the db
1. new registry is added to the DB. 
1. add `POST` endpoint that supports the new crawler, registry pair: `[POST] /api/crawler/:crawler/:registryID` see #627 for reference
1. faktory worker that consumes task sent to queue by step 1 and starts nuget discovery
1. discovery crawls and the payloads that trigger them are recorded in the DB and associated with all components discovered in the crawl
1. newly discovered components are added to the component database. 
1. metadata that does not align with the current columns should be inserted into the `additional_metadata` column.
1. if possible, record metadata about the crawl so that subsequent discovery crawls will not redo the same work
### Deployment
* create kube deployment config for discovery worker(s)
* deploy worker(s)
* [passive] trigger discovery job by pushing to the queue, monitor for unexpected behavior/failures (e.g. surprising number of errors, rate limits, 503s, etc ...)
* [passive] monitor max/min pod memory and cpu usage. Adjust worker pod resource limits and requests to support more efficient pod packing per node.

### Metrics
* estimate max number of components
* estimate rate of discovery (components/sec) (min 2 hour window)
* estimate time to complete discovery 

## Analysis
### Code Changes
* ensure that component downloader supports the download type for each component that is discovered. If already supported, no additional work needs to be done in this section
* if download type is unsupported, add that support.

### Analysis Execution
* Push nuget components to queue `NUGET-analysis` with:
  * commenStrippedSha and declaredLicenseScan enabled
  * discoveredLicnse scan disabled
  * 30 min timeout
  * 3 retries
* add a nuget analysis worker kube deployment in f2-kube repo
* deploy worker that consumes from `NUGET-analysis` queue
* [passive] monitor for unexpected errors and rate limits using kibana. [go/ramjet-worker-dashboard](http://go/ramjet-worker-dashboard) is a good starting point.
* [passive] monitor max/min pod memory and cpu usage. Adjust worker pod resource limits and requests to support more efficient pod packing per node. 

### Metrics
* estimate rate of analysis (components/sec) (min 3 hour window)
* estimate time to complete analysis for nuget
* determine baseline error rate so we can identify when things are going wrong
   *  e.g. in 1 hour, 10,000 successful analysis tasks and 500 failed tasks as a baseline would hint that we should be concerned if during another 1 hr window there is a 4,000 successful tasks and 8,000 failed tasks


# Notes
* More than 1 faktory worker can be made for this. It is likely that there will be a fanout-like workflow
* There are always unexpected edge cases from real world data. Aim to follow the 80/20 rule. Downstream consumers may be able to work with 80% success in discovery &/or analysis.
* There may be rate limits, but they seem very high. If we need to get around them, we can try to build out the IP rate limit bypass as a service.
* The [f2 project may be a good reference](https://github.com/fossas/f2/tree/master/services/crawlers/nuget) for an older implementation of this type of service. As a warning it uses netflix's conductor orchestration framework instead of faktory. 
* docs on the nuget registry server can be found [here](https://github.com/fossas/f2/tree/master/services/crawlers/nugethttps://github.com/fossas/f2/tree/master/services/crawlers/nuget)

title: Monitor RPM analysis

labels.name: passive
labels.description: Tasks that can generally be performed in the background

body:
# Description
RPM analysis has been failing due to 503 service not responding errors because we've likely been taking down their servers.

This happens with 1 or more pods, sometimes at random, and seems to be happening with fedora. The way around this has been: run 1-10 pods at a time, then occassionally check when 503s are being hit.

When that happens, spin down the pods, wait 30 minutes, start them up again and re-queue the components that failed due to the 503.

Right now you can just use the query 
```sql
select component.id from component 
join crawl on crawl.id=component.crawl and crawler=21 and analysis_state='failed' order by registry desc;
```
to get all of the RPM components that failed. If we start getting a high number of _non service not available_ failures, we can look to change the query to be more focused.

Remember to clear the existing queue when requeuing as you might end up redundantly queuing components by accident.
# Tasks
* queue RPM comonents for analysis in `RPM-analysis` queue
* turn on RPM analysis pods. Start at 1, increase to 4-10 until the service outage hits
* periodically check for logs for service failures. Turn off pods, re-queue components, go to the beginning of this task list

title: Move Ramjet migrations from ramjet/migrations/ to ramjet/internal/migrations/
body:
## Background
Ramjet's migrations are stored in ramjet/migrations. Other projects store their migrations in <project>/internal/migrations. Moving the Ramjet migrations to ramjet/internal/migrations lets use benefit from shared database tooling (eg. package `migrate`, some defaults for package `ephemeraldb`)

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Migrations are moved.
2. Aragog references to migrations (eg. README) are updated
3. Ramjet references to migrations are updated
    i. All `mage.MigrateUp` and `mage.MigrateUp` used in tests with a hardcoded string should now make use of the shared tooling `migrate` functionality. Note that the list below is not exhaustive.
        `ramjet/internal/cmd/rpm-discovery/insert_test.go`
        `ramjet/internal/lib/analysis/dbsetup_test.go`
        `ramjet/internal/testing/shared/component_test_util.go`
        `ramjet/pkg/filestore/test_common_test.go`
        `ramjet/pkg/component-service/insert_test.go`
    ii. All places where hardcoded migration strings used in main.go files should now make use of the shared tooling `migrate` functionality. Note that the list below is not exhaustive.
        `ramjet/internal/cmd/component-analyzer-cli/main.go`
4. Review `ramjet/mage` and update to make use of the shared tooling `migrate` package.

title: investigate infrastructure/framework to assess registry server stability
body:
# Goals
Investigate a performance testing/grading framework to assess the performance profile of registry response time and availability so that we can get the following benefits:
* proactively prevent accidentally taking down a 3rd party service
* accurately predict the length of time needed to complete a long running task that is putting load and relying on a third party registry

# Background
Different registries hit during discovery and fingerprinting had different performance profiles. Some, like nuget, were incredibly stable and offered a consistent response time under varying loads.

Sites like jcenter and certain RPM registries did not deliver consistent performance over varying load profiles. Without having a great way of knowing what the performance profile of a particular registry is, we needed to make guesses as to how long certain tasks (disco, fingerprinting) would take. 

This was generally fine until we started to have the same workers consuming from registries of the same type but different sources. With RPM, we were able to use the same analysis pathways, but sourced RPMs from multiple registries. This became abundantly clear when we started facing a wave of 503s when those servers were under light load, compared to the 10-100x scale we were running against for earlier registries of type RPM

# Proposal
Create a standardization for how to assess the performance profile of a registry under differing loads. The goal would be to determine if:
* there is a relationship between load from our workers and the server performance
  * if at 1, 10, 100, and 1000 concurrent workers, the response could be: unaffected, degrade linearly, degrade superlinearly, or degrade sublinearly
  * is there a limit to the load before the registry is taken offline accidentally (503s)
  * is there a (documented or undocumented) rate limit? If so, is it by IP address, by header, or by some other mechanism?

title: Taskqueue: task not found
body:
## What

This PR:

* Updates `package taskqueue` to exit the worker if it encounters `ERR Job not found` from the Faktory worker.
* Adds `logging.Interceptor` to support functionality like this.

## Why

Sherlock has issues where workers are getting out of sync with the server, causing them to become stuck forever.
This PR prevents them from getting stuck at least.

## How

Inspect logging output from `package faktoryWorker`, exit the program if we get matching log lines.

## Security Impact

None.

Checklist:
- [x] Code in this PR is covered by automated tests.

## Dependency Changes

None

title: Large call trace in kube logs for RPM analysis
body:
# Description
Large call trace errors are popping up in RPM analysis on kube. Reason is not currently known, nor is there a hypothesis atm.

# How to find trace
* Go to RPM pods, select pod with many restarts. 
* Go to logs
* Hit the triple dot more options button in the top right, select the previous logs option
* search for the trace, this might need a few tries to find a pod that had this case

# Example trace
(partial)

title: RPM analysis
body:
# Description
Finish/track RPM analysis. Resolve bugs in runtime analyiss

# Query to find failed rpm components
`select analysis_failure_reason, name, version, revision, component.id from component join crawl on component.crawl=crawl.id and crawler=21 and analysis_state='failed';`

Gives failure reason: we should hopefully be able to group these to find categories of failures.
Allows us to track components that failed and were otherwise fixed.

# Why Create a Story?
We've encountered a few bugs with RPM analysis. I wanted to capture/group them under a story that could be tracked independently

title: Template issue for validating analysis worker output
